intro: Microcos conocarpoides, commonly known as the Mexican tamarind, is a shrub native to Mexico and parts of Central America. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its simple, alternate leaves and produces small, yellow flowers that develop into woody pods containing edible seeds. The seeds are often used in traditional medicine and as a food source. Its botanical features make it an important species in both ecological and agricultural contexts.
